text: i have no mental imagery. no inner voice. my long-term memory works through concepts and associations, not images or sounds. i can't picture my mother's face or replay a song in my head.

my only ambition for the first 20 years was to become a lawyer and own nice things. then in my late teens i realized i care deeply about life around me — and in fact, in the entire universe. that was the end of the lawyer plan. what followed was a rabbit hole through animal rights, effective altruism, and biosecurity policy at the biological weapons convention. each shift felt like a reinvention. looking back, the thread was always the same — find the highest-leverage thing.

lived a year near nashville through afs when i was 15. it made me spiritually very american — i genuinely appreciate the culture, including the hardcore religion, respect for veterans and elders, and the community bonds that come with it. it also gave me an understanding of how all that can lead to electing trump. individualism and community have to be anchored and go hand in hand to maintain the tightrope walk that drives societal progress. and america is the most skilled at tolerating the high volatility that comes with being at the frontier.

was vegan for three years but now think meat makes reliable nutrition significantly easier for most people — especially for key nutrients like b12, iron, and complete amino acid profiles. the nutrition industry is currently mostly a scam; the actual science deserves better than the fad-diet grifters sitting on top of it.

played drums and trumpet. badly. i unfortunately wasn't taught to appreciate the discipline necessary to get really good, and only through my enjoyment of dancing did i get motivated to actually think about music theory. what i figured out is that what i care about is the generation of flow states. i still hope to get into my drum machine and learn to produce — but that's for post-scarcity.

i enjoy being sore — whether from hiit or deep stretching, fully feeling into my body is one of my favorite things. as a kid i did competitive gymnastics, then road and mountain bike races as a teenager, then rowing. these days it's rock climbing, yoga, weights, and i recently discovered fighting monkey. my primary mode of transport in geneva is cycling — car-free by choice.

i write a lot of google reviews because i think it's a public good. good places deserve visibility, bad places deserve accountability, and shaming is good actually. but mostly i try to leave positive reviews — focus on what you want to see more of.
i got certified as a snowboard instructor but only taught one season. turns out it pays terribly, and most of the kids just had a wet butt and complained.
